frameDefinitions: A group of Arguers (also expressible as Arguer1 and Arguer2) express incompatible opinions or beliefs about an Issue.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
The Support, a phenomenon or fact,  lends support to a claim or proposed course of action, the Proposition, where the Domain_of_relevance may also be expressed.

This frame consists of words that describe a hostile encounter between opposing forces (Side_1 and Side_2, collectively conceptualizable as Sides) over a disputed Issue and/or in order to reach a specific  Purpose. '' 'He still wants to fight Mike Tyson in about 8 months.'
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
frameExamples: We <t>bickered</t> about semantics for an hour.
The latest poll results <t>show</t> that support of the president is at an all-time low.
He still wants to <t>fight</t> Mike Tyson in about 8 months.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
listRoleDefinitions: A group of people in an argument.
A person who is arguing with Arguer2.
The person who is being argued with by <fen>Arguer1</fen>.
The the thing the the <fen>Arguers</fen> are arguing over or about.
The time when the argument takes place.
The location at which the <fen>Arguers</fen> quarrel
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
Support is a fact that lends epistemic support to a claim, or that provides a reason for a course of action. Typically it is expressed as an External Argument.
This is a belief, claim, or proposed course of action to which the Support lends validity. Normally it is expressed as a Finite Clause Complement:
One of two participants in a hostile encounter.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter, usually the second mentioned.
The jointly expressed sides in a hostile encounter.
An unresolved question over which the two sides of a hostile encounter are in disagreement.

The desired result of the outcome of the hostile encounter for the <fen>Side_1</fen> or for all the <fen>Sides</fen> collectively.  It may either directly refer to the state of affairs that is desired, e.g.
The <fex name='Time'>Time</fex> at which the hostile encounter occurs.
The location at which the hostile encounter takes place.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: Why are you arguing <fex>with us</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
<fex>The fact that you lied to me</fex> shows that I shouldn't trust you.
The fact that you lied to me shows <fex>that I shouldn't trust you</fex>.
While <fex>the U.S.'s</fex> battle with terrorist-harboring nations is far off ...
While the U.S.'s battle <fex>with terrorist-harboring nations</fex> is far off ...
<fex>They</fex> fought over the right to own land.
They had a dust-up <fex>over who was prettier</fex> .
He dueled with his former second <fex>to defend the honour of the man he had killed</fex> .
Following the battle of Naseby <fex>in 1645</fex> he died.
Following the battle <fex>of Naseby</fex> in 1645 ...
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
<fex>Evelyn</fex> spoke feelingly about what happened.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Evelyn spoke candidly <fex>about her past</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
